text: whoa whoa whoa hi everyone both in iwo
tano here the internet's busiest music
nerd and it's time for a review of the
new lady gaga remix album dawn of
chromatica this is a new remix album
from one of pop's biggest icons and
strongest voices lady gaga with well
over a decade of hits and outlandish
outfits under her belt right now one may
expect her at this time in her career to
maybe be slowing down creatively but no
actually in my opinion the chromatica
era has shown to be just as wild and
uncompromising as many of her album
rollouts so far and i also think the
record chromatica was pretty quality too
with numerous tracks that celebrated
more classic forms of house and dance
pop now the record came out
it was good i think gaga could have
easily left it there and moved on but
instead we have a remix album and this
remix album could have easily been
something that
gaga played relatively straight with a
series of producers or singers that
handed in really accessible edm
revisions of the tracks on the record
but no dawn of chromatica is actually
one of the riskiest most adventurous and
insane remix projects to drop from any
artist at gaga's level as she really
leaned into the growing community of
hyper pop producers as well as queer
leaning pop artists now with that being
said this thing is still a remix album
so of course it does
suffer from some of the same issues that
a lot of remix albums do not every remix
hits and of course the respective
artistic visions of each artist on this
project
they don't they don't always line up but
gaga giving everyone involved on this
thing a lot of creative freedom
and believe me there's a lot of creative
freedom it has led to some real
highlights like arca's version of rain
on me with ariana grande is almost like
an anti-remix of sorts the whole thing
feels like i'm being edged musically for
several long lasting minutes rather than
delivering a hard drop the further the
song goes along it's like it gets more
indirect and spacey given arca's
abstract and experimental pedigree i
guess this is something i should have
seen coming but yeah even though this
one's a little left field i will say the
more i listen to it and the more i sort
of understand what it's going for the
more i appreciate it and the more that i
hear it's easily one of the most
texturally and sonically creative
remixes here though it's maybe more for
headphones than it is the dance floor
then with the track fun tonight pablo
vittar
reinvents this one with almost a tejano
flair complete with a accordion and
everything and it's so good i feel like
this version really enhances the vocal
melody of the track it feels almost uh
romantic by comparison and it comes off
so natural and organic if i had heard
this first i would be convinced it was
an original not a remix at all with 911
charlie xcx and a.g cook tear it up in a
way that i appreciate because it's not
like so obviously pandering to the hyper
pop fans that may be expecting them to
sound a very specific way on this song
there's a sparkling intro on this track
a lot of driving throbbing eerie techno
beats a surprising amount of saxophone
too that brings us into this heavy
rhythmic odyssey then the whole thing
kind of turns into a glossy trap ballad
on the tail end with gagas and charlie's
vocals kind of
swapping in and out here and there each
sounding great it's a multi-phased remix
that has a lot of character to it then
plastic doll with ash nico i'm not crazy
about this one but what i like about it
is that it's a quirky and futuristic pop
and wrap fusion that very much fits her
style given the sentiment of the song
the message of it i feel like this track
was right up ashniko's alley and she
really turned it into her own thing then
this version of sour candy from shy girl
and muramasa is not nearly as bright or
as playful as the original and that's
kind of what i like about it there's
something a lot more serious and
sinister about uh the approach taken on
this remix especially thanks to the
cerebral dance beats pushing away in the
background and shy girl's very low key
and moody vocal delivery the dorian
remix is one that i was most looking
forward to on this project they
absolutely kill it here with some heavy
chugging metal guitars that kind of call
back to the my agenda project but
totally work here too it's a crazy mix
of heavy metal music and dance that i
hope the gaga fans are ready for then
sign from above with elton john the
remix of this track with chester
lockhart mood killer and a little texas
doing some hard style on the back end
this is one of the most insane things i
think i've i've ever heard it's a track
that's really disorienting but fun one
that i had to listen to multiple times
to really kind of get a grasp of it
because mood killer is just throwing so
much at the mix at once and always
changing things up aesthetically uh
throwing in some wild transitions there
are so many tongue-in-cheek edits on the
track too from some of the uh glitchy
skips in elton john's voice to uh that
line where um elton and gaga are singing
before there was love there was silence
but then of course when silence is said
it cuts to silence with the song being
titled sign from above there's even a
quick fraction of a second where we're
just hit with the sound of a sine wave i
think for some people this version of
the track may be a little much but
considering this wasn't necessarily one
of my faves from the
original chromatica record i i might
enjoy this version just a bit more then
the jimmy edgar remix of babylon is
great too a more synthetic and smooth
presentation of the track while still
maintaining its anthemic songwriting and
structure and i think bree runway was a
fantastic addition to the song too so
yeah there were great cuts all over this
thing i do have some reservations about
a few tracks the second remix of babylon
i thought was kind of unnecessary there
aren't really enough creative liberties
taken with
the opening remix either the dos remix
of enigma i thought was easily the
weakest on the project some of the vocal
samples on this one don't really line up
all that well and stylistically
i thought this beat wasn't nearly as
bold as the bulk of the material here
too i wish the free woman remix went
further honestly i think rina does a
great job vocally on this version of the
track which is no surprise considering
how great that song she did with elton
came out but instrumentally i feel like
i'm mostly listening to the same song
but a more cluttered
i guess version of it that i don't think
um really enhances the experience
necessarily but again with all that
being said i thought dawn of chromatica
was a really fun new way to enjoy this
gaga record love that she's platforming
some artists who absolutely deserve it
from people like planning to rock who
have been at this for a while to some of
the new groundbreakers out there and i
hope if you guys listen to it don't
expect every track to gel with you don't
expect every track to blow you away but
uh the the cuts on here that are
fantastic i hope you find them as
exciting and as creative as i do i'm
feeling a strong six to a light seven on
this one tran position have you given
this record a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head is another video that you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
lady gaga dawn of chromatica
forever
